snippet: More than half of the general election advertising aired by outside groups in the battle for control of Congress has come from organizations that disclose little or nothing about their donors.
abstract: More than half of general election advertising aired by outside groups in battle for control of Congress has come from organizations that disclose little or nothing about their donors; advertising is largely paid for by nonprofit groups and trade associations, some of which are established with purpose of shielding wealthy individuals and corporations that contribute; flow of secret money is at center of debate over line between free speech and corruption.
lead_paragraph: More than half of the general election advertising aired by outside groups in the battle for control of Congress has come from organizations that disclose little or nothing about their donors.

headline.main: Secret Money Fueling a Flood of Political Ads
headline.print_headline: Secret Money Fueling a Flood of Political Ads

keywords.value: Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)
keywords.name: subject
